content.body: Unfortunately that doesn't work, async generator functions will not reenter until all previous next calls settle

content.formatted_body:
async function* foo() {
    yield new Promise(r => setTimeout(r, 1000));
    console.log('reenter');
}
const it = foo();
it.next();
it.next();

content.body: the previous call settles in my example
The `reenter` won't log until the 1000ms is up
content.formatted_body: The reenter won't log until the 1000ms is up

content.body: yes but it doesn't need to
my example still works

content.formatted_body:
async function* foo(){ yield 0; await sleep(1000); yield 1; }
let it = foo().map(x => fetch(x));
it.next();
// almost immediately after this point, the promise returned from the first call to the underlying foo()'s `.next` settles
// then the first call to `fetch` starts
it.next() // so this can almost immediately kick off another call to the underlying foo()'s `next`, and have that actually hit the `sleep`

m.new_content.formatted_body:

let it = foo().map(x => fetch(x));
it.next();
// almost immediately after this point, the promise returned from the first call to the underlying foo()'s `.next` settles
// then the first call to `fetch` starts
it.next() // so this can almost immediately kick off another call to the underlying foo()'s `next`, and have that actually hit the `sleep`

content.formatted_body:
async function* foo(){
    yield 0;
    console.log('reenter');
    await sleep(1000);
    yield 1;
}
let it = foo();
it.next();
it.next();
console.log('end');

Logs end then reenter, the first yield doesn't settle the iterator until after a tick

content.body: here's code you can run today which demonstrates that the mapper from the slides can be parallel, both from with itself and with the underlying generator https://gist.github.com/bakkot/a338838aee667517adb03edfa83aaed1

and indeed the original generator can't be parallel with itself. I don't think there's anything we can do about that, though - the whole point of generators is that they're written as straight-line code, and you can't start executing the next line until the previous one finishes

😦 Before my time
Ah, surprising but maybe for the best. In any case, “overdriving” (drawing concurrent promises from next()) a pipeline of async maps to get parallelism is useful, so glad that’ll work regardless.

content.formatted_body:
In fact, the implicit await is doing me a big favor in:

function parallel(limit, process) {
  function *workers() {
    for (const worker of count(limit)) {
      yield process(worker);
    }
  }
  return Promise.all(workers());
}

content.body:
Out of which you can build bounded concurrency pretty easily (I’m taking the liberty of assuming the existence of AsyncIterator.from having not followed along particularly closely)

```
AsyncIterator.prototype.parallelForEach = async (limit, values, process) =>
  parallel(limit, () => AsyncIterator.from(values).forEach(process));
```

content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org

In fact, the implicit await is doing me a big favor in:

function parallel(limit, process) {
  function *workers() {
    for (const worker of count(limit)) {
      yield process(worker);
    }
  }
  return Promise.all(workers());
}
There's no async iterator there and so no implicit await; did you mean a different thing?

content.body:
> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> Out of which you can build bounded concurrency pretty easily (I’m taking the liberty of assuming the existence of AsyncIterator.from having not followed along particularly closely)

>   parallel(limit, () => AsyncIterator.from(values).forEach(process));

content.body: I wonder how difficult it would be to change to Option 2, which would allow easy parallel processing

The only way to consume async iterables:
- Callers of `.next()` will await (they already had to, we're returning promises)
- for-await-of can be updated to await the inner value
  - Also call `.return()` if rejection happens
content.formatted_body:
The only way to consume async iterables:

  • Callers of .next() will await (they already had to, we're returning promises)
  • for-await-of can be updated to await the inner value
    • Also call .return() if rejection happens

content.body: Surprisingly, I don't think there'll be a web-compat risk.

The ways to consume an async iterator:
- manual `.next()`
- `yield*` (which only works inside another async iterable)
- `for-await-of`
content.formatted_body:
The ways to consume an async iterator:

  • manual .next()
  • yield* (which only works inside another async iterable)
  • for-await-of

content.body: I don't imagine manual `.next()` iteration is super common?
content.formatted_body: I don't imagine manual .next() iteration is super common?

content.body: So the main way to consume an async iterable is to use `for-await-of`, which we can update to await the inner promise (and cleanup the iterator on rejections)
content.formatted_body: So the main way to consume an async iterable is to use for-await-of, which we can update to await the inner promise (and cleanup the iterator on rejections)

content.body: We can ignore `yield*`, because it's only available in other async iterators, because we still have an async iterator and that still needs to be consumed with `for-await-of`.
content.formatted_body: We can ignore yield*, because it's only available in other async iterators, because we still have an async iterator and that still needs to be consumed with for-await-of.

content.body: `.next()` iteration could be updated to await the inner value, but not block on that settlement
content.formatted_body: .next() iteration could be updated to await the inner value, but not block on that settlement

content.body: Or maybe we need a `.nextRaw()` which won't unwrap the inner
content.formatted_body: Or maybe we need a .nextRaw() which won't unwrap the inner

content.body: the main web-compat risk is that `(async function*(){ try { yield Promise.reject(1) } catch (e) { console.log('caught'); } })().next()` prints `caught`
content.formatted_body: the main web-compat risk is that (async function*(){ try { yield Promise.reject(1) } catch (e) { console.log('caught'); } })().next() prints caught

content.body: i.e. yielding a rejected promise triggers `catch` handlers around the yield
content.formatted_body: i.e. yielding a rejected promise triggers catch handlers around the yield

content.body: changing that would be fraught at this point
A `.nextRaw()` then

content.formatted_body:
Eg, the slides say:

// Given:
AsyncIterator.prototype = {
  async next(v) {
    return { value: await resumeWithValue(v), done }
  }

  async error(e) {
    return { value: await resumeWithError(e), done }
  }
}

// Input
async function* foo() {
    try {
        yield Promise.reject(1);
    } finally {
        console.log(2);
    }
}

// Output
async function* foo() {
    try {
        yield await Promise.reject(1);
    } finally {
        console.log(2);
    }
}

content.body: I think we could unobservably change that to:

content.formatted_body:
// Given:
AsyncIterator.prototype = {
  async next(v) {
    try {
      return { value: await resumeWithValue(v), done }
    } catch (e) {
      return { value: await resumeWithError(e), done }
    }
  }

  async error(e) {
    return { value: await resumeWithError(e), done }
  }
}

// Input
async function* foo() {
    try {
        yield Promise.reject(1);
    } finally {
        console.log(2);
    }
}

// Output has no change

And if we can do that, why can't we do:

// Given:
AsyncIterator.prototype = {
  async next(v) {
    try {
      return { value: await this.nextRaw(v).value, done }
    } catch (e) {
      return { value: await resumeWithError(e), done }
    }
  }

  async nextRaw(v) {
    return { value: resumeWithValue(v), done }
  }

  async error(e) {
    return { value: await resumeWithError(e), done }
  }
}
